sites.title: Zócalo (Plaza de la Constitución)
sites.address: Plaza de la Constitución, Centro, 06000 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Vast central plaza that was the ceremonial heart of Tenochtitlan and remains Mexico’s main square.
sites.description_md:
# Zócalo

Covering 57,600 square metres, the Zócalo has been a gathering space since Aztec times. It is bordered by the Metropolitan Cathedral, National Palace and Government buildings and hosts national events and protests.

sites.title: Templo Mayor
sites.address: Seminario 8, Centro Histórico de la Ciudad de México, 06060 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Main temple of the Mexica dedicated to gods Huitzilopochtli and Tlaloc, excavated in the 20th century.
sites.description_md:
# Templo Mayor

This dual pyramid was rebuilt several times between 1325 and 1521. Spanish conquistadors destroyed it and built Mexico City over the ruins. Excavations have revealed offerings and sculptures now displayed in the on-site museum.

sites.title: Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe
sites.address: Plaza de las Américas 1, Villa de Guadalupe, 07050 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Major Catholic pilgrimage site housing the cloak said to bear an image of the Virgin Mary.
sites.description_md:
# Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe

The modern basilica, completed in 1976, stands near the Old Basilica and contains the tilma of Saint Juan Diego. Millions visit annually, especially around the feast day on December 12.

sites.title: Frida Kahlo Museum (Casa Azul)
sites.address: Londres 247, Del Carmen, Coyoacán, 04100 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Artist Frida Kahlo’s blue house turned museum displaying her art, belongings and studio.
sites.description_md:
# Frida Kahlo Museum

Located in the Coyoacán district, the Casa Azul offers a glimpse into the life of Frida Kahlo and her husband Diego Rivera. The museum preserves her personal artefacts, artworks and lush courtyard.

sites.title: Xochimilco Canals
sites.address: Xochimilco, 16070 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Network of Aztec canals and floating gardens navigated by colourful trajinera boats.
sites.description_md:
# Xochimilco Canals

A UNESCO World Heritage site, Xochimilco retains remnants of the lake system that once covered the Valley of Mexico. Visitors ride painted boats through canals lined with chinampas (floating fields).

sites.title: Coyoacán Historic Centre
sites.address: Coyoacán, 04000 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Cobblestone district south of the centre known for colonial plazas, cafés and a bohemian vibe.
sites.description_md:
# Coyoacán Historic Centre

This area encompasses 29 blocks of cobbled streets around plazas like Jardín Centenario. Once a separate village, Coyoacán retains a relaxed atmosphere with markets, churches and the house where Hernán Cortés lived.

sites.title: Palacio de Bellas Artes
sites.address: Av. Juárez, Centro Histórico de la Ciudad de México, 06050 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Ornate art nouveau and art deco palace hosting operas, concerts and murals by famous Mexican artists.
sites.description_md:
# Palacio de Bellas Artes

Construction of this cultural centre began in 1904 and concluded in 1934. Its interior features murals by Diego Rivera and David Alfaro Siqueiros, while the theatre’s stained‑glass curtain depicts the Valley of Mexico.

sites.title: Torre Latinoamericana
sites.address: Eje Central Lázaro Cárdenas 2, Centro, 06000 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: 166‑metre skyscraper famed for surviving earthquakes and offering panoramic observation decks.
sites.description_md:
# Torre Latinoamericana

Opened in 1956, this tower stood as Mexico’s tallest building for decades. It withstood the 1957 and 1985 earthquakes thanks to advanced engineering and has an observation deck and museum on the 44th floor.

sites.title: Chapultepec Castle
sites.address: Bosque de Chapultepec I Sección, 11100 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Castle atop Chapultepec Hill that served as a military academy, imperial residence and presidential palace.
sites.description_md:
# Chapultepec Castle

Perched on a hill 2,325 metres above sea level, this 18th‑century castle was built for viceroys and later became the home of Emperor Maximilian I. It now houses the National Museum of History.

sites.title: National Palace (Mexico City)
sites.address: Plaza de la Constitución S/N, Centro, 06000 Ciudad de México, CDMX, Mexico
sites.summary: Seat of the federal executive branch adorned with Diego Rivera murals depicting Mexico’s history.
sites.description_md:
# National Palace

Built on the site of Moctezuma II’s palace, the National Palace houses government offices and ceremonial rooms. Its arcaded courtyards display murals illustrating Mexico’s past.
